title: Probability Theory
text:
# Assignment 1
# Define the given values
probability_S <- 0.3
probability_not_S <- 0.7
conditional_probability_T_given_S <- 0.2
conditional_probability_T_given_not_S <- 0.6
conditional_probability_not_T_given_S <- 0.8
conditional_probability_not_T_given_not_S <- 0.4

# Calculate the probabilities
probability_T_and_S <- conditional_probability_T_given_S * probability_S
probability_T_and_not_s <- conditional_probability_T_given_not_S * probability_not_S
probability_not_T_and_S <- conditional_probability_not_T_given_S * probability_S
probability_not_T_and_not_S <- conditional_probability_not_T_given_not_S * probability_not_S
total_sum <- probability_T_and_S + probability_T_and_not_s + probability_not_T_and_S + probability_not_T_and_not_S

# Display the probabilities and the sum
cat("P(T ∩ S):",probability_T_and_S , "\n")

#> P(T ∩ S): 0.06

cat("P(T ∩ S'): ",probability_T_and_not_s, "\n")

#> P(T ∩ S'):  0.42

cat("P(T' ∩ S): ",probability_not_T_and_S, "\n")

#> P(T' ∩ S):  0.24

cat("P(T' ∩ S'): ",probability_not_T_and_not_S, "\n\n")

#> P(T' ∩ S'):  0.28

cat("Sum of all four probabilities:", total_sum, "\n")

#> Sum of all four probabilities: 1



# Assignment 2
# Assuming you have the percentages
percentage_all_three <- 0.5
percentage_at_least_two <- 19.9
percentage_only_one <- 80.1

# Display the percentages
cat("Percentage of customers using all three devices:", percentage_all_three, "%\n")

#> Percentage of customers using all three devices: 0.5 %

cat("Percentage of customers using at least two devices:", percentage_at_least_two, "%\n")

#> Percentage of customers using at least two devices: 19.9 %

cat("Percentage of customers using only one device:", percentage_only_one, "%\n")

#> Percentage of customers using only one device: 80.1 %



# Assignment 3
# Given probabilities
P_A <- 0.04
P_B_given_A <- 0.97
P_B_given_not_A <- 0.01

# Calculate complementary probability
P_not_A <- 1 - P_A

# Calculate total probability of triggering an alarm
P_B <- P_B_given_A * P_A + P_B_given_not_A * P_not_A

# Apply Bayes' theorem
P_not_A_given_B <- (P_B_given_not_A * P_not_A) / P_B
P_A_given_B <- (P_B_given_A * P_A) / P_B

# Display the results
cat("These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about", P_not_A_given_B * 100, "% that the product is flawless and a probability of about", P_A_given_B * 100, "% that the product is faulty.\n")

#> These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.83471 % that the product is flawless and a probability of about 80.16529 % that the product is faulty.

title: Causality
text:
# Install and load necessary packages
library(ggplot2)

# Create random data for a spurious correlation
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  crude_oil_imports = rnorm(100, mean = 62, sd = 40.54),
  train_collisions = rnorm(100, mean = 64.909, sd = 12.26)
)

# Add a color variable to distinguish between the two variables
data$variable <- rep(c("crude_oil_imports", "train_collisions"), each = 50)
# Create a scatter plot
ggplot(data, aes(x = crude_oil_imports, y = train_collisions, color = variable)) +
  geom_point() +
  ggtitle("Spurious Correlation") +
  xlab("US crude oil imports from Norway") +
  ylab("Drivers killed in collision with railway train") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("crude_oil_imports" = "blue", "train_collisions" = "red"))

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
random_vars <- readRDS("C:/Users/Anjali/Downloads/Causal_Data_Science_Data (1)/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")

# 1

# Expected value (mean) for each variable
expected_values <- sapply(random_vars, mean)

# Variance for each variable
variances <- sapply(random_vars, var)

# Standard deviation for each variable
standard_deviations <- sapply(random_vars, sd)

# Display the results
results <- data.frame(
  Variable = names(random_vars),
  Expected_Value = expected_values,
  Variance = variances,
  Standard_Deviation = standard_deviations
)

results



  




Comparing standard deviations is not always appropriate, especially when variables have different measurement units or represent fundamentally different characteristics. Additionally, standard deviations should be interpreted in conjunction with other statistical measures and the specific goals of the analysis.


#3

# Covariance between two variables
covariance_value <- cov(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)

# Correlation between two variables
correlation_value <- cor(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)

# Display the results
relationship_results <- data.frame(
  Variable1 = "age",
  Variable2 = "income",
  Covariance = covariance_value,
  Correlation = correlation_value
)

relationship_results



  




The correlation is generally easier to interpret compared to covariance, as it is a standardized measure that ranges from -1 to 1.Here the measure of correlation is 0.5479432, which suggests a moderate positive linear relationship. A positive correlation implies that as one variable increases, the other tends to increase as well. The magnitude of 0.5479432 indicates a moderate strength of the relationship. The closer the correlation coefficient is to 1, the stronger the positive linear relationship.


#5

# Compute conditional expected value for age <= 18
conditional_expected_value_age_less_than_18 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age <= 18])

# Compute conditional expected value for age in [18, 65)
conditional_expected_value_age_18_to_65 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age >= 18 & random_vars$age < 65])

# Compute conditional expected value for age >= 65
conditional_expected_value_age_greater_than_65 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age >= 65])

# Display the results
conditional_expected_values <- data.frame(
  Age_Group = c("Age <= 18", "Age ∈ [18, 65)", "Age >= 65"),
  Conditional_Expected_Value = c(
    conditional_expected_value_age_less_than_18,
    conditional_expected_value_age_18_to_65,
    conditional_expected_value_age_greater_than_65
  )
)

conditional_expected_values

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
#1
data <- readRDS("C:/Users/Anjali/Downloads/Causal_Data_Science_Data (1)/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")
# Assuming your data is stored in a variable named 'data'
data_dimensions <- dim(data)

# Printing the number of rows and columns
print(paste("Number of rows:", data_dimensions[1]))

#> [1] "Number of rows: 181"

print(paste("Number of columns:", data_dimensions[2]))

#> [1] "Number of columns: 22"



#2
# Use str() to get the structure of the data
str(data)

#> Classes 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame':    181 obs. of  22 variables:
#>  $ aspiration      : chr  "std" "std" "std" "std" ...
#>  $ doornumber      : chr  "two" "two" "two" "four" ...
#>  $ carbody         : chr  "convertible" "convertible" "hatchback" "sedan" ...
#>  $ drivewheel      : chr  "rwd" "rwd" "rwd" "fwd" ...
#>  $ enginelocation  : chr  "front" "front" "front" "front" ...
#>  $ wheelbase       : num  88.6 88.6 94.5 99.8 99.4 ...
#>  $ carlength       : num  169 169 171 177 177 ...
#>  $ carwidth        : num  64.1 64.1 65.5 66.2 66.4 66.3 71.4 71.4 71.4 67.9 ...
#>  $ carheight       : num  48.8 48.8 52.4 54.3 54.3 53.1 55.7 55.7 55.9 52 ...
#>  $ curbweight      : num  2548 2548 2823 2337 2824 ...
#>  $ enginetype      : chr  "dohc" "dohc" "ohcv" "ohc" ...
#>  $ cylindernumber  : chr  "four" "four" "six" "four" ...
#>  $ enginesize      : num  130 130 152 109 136 136 136 136 131 131 ...
#>  $ fuelsystem      : chr  "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" ...
#>  $ boreratio       : num  3.47 3.47 2.68 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.13 3.13 ...
#>  $ stroke          : num  2.68 2.68 3.47 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 ...
#>  $ compressionratio: num  9 9 9 10 8 8.5 8.5 8.5 8.3 7 ...
#>  $ horsepower      : num  111 111 154 102 115 110 110 110 140 160 ...
#>  $ peakrpm         : num  5000 5000 5000 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 ...
#>  $ citympg         : num  21 21 19 24 18 19 19 19 17 16 ...
#>  $ highwaympg      : num  27 27 26 30 22 25 25 25 20 22 ...
#>  $ price           : num  13495 16500 16500 13950 17450 ...

# Use summary() for a summary of the data
summary(data)

#>   aspiration         doornumber          carbody           drivewheel       
#>  Length:181         Length:181         Length:181         Length:181        
#>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>  enginelocation       wheelbase        carlength        carwidth

#>  Class :character   1st Qu.: 94.50   1st Qu.:166.3   1st Qu.:64.00  
#>  Mode  :character   Median : 96.50   Median :173.0   Median :65.40  
#>                     Mean   : 98.21   Mean   :173.3   Mean   :65.74  
#>                     3rd Qu.:100.40   3rd Qu.:180.2   3rd Qu.:66.50  
#>                     Max.   :120.90   Max.   :208.1   Max.   :72.30  
#>    carheight       curbweight    enginetype        cylindernumber    
#>  Min.   :47.80   Min.   :1488   Length:181         Length:181        
#>  1st Qu.:52.00   1st Qu.:2122   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Median :53.70   Median :2410   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>  Mean   :53.58   Mean   :2521                                        
#>  3rd Qu.:55.50   3rd Qu.:2910                                        
#>  Max.   :59.80   Max.   :4066                                        
#>    enginesize     fuelsystem          boreratio         stroke    
#>  Min.   : 61.0   Length:181         Min.   :2.540   Min.   :2.07  
#>  1st Qu.: 98.0   Class :character   1st Qu.:3.150   1st Qu.:3.08  
#>  Median :120.0   Mode  :character   Median :3.310   Median :3.23  
#>  Mean   :127.1                      Mean   :3.325   Mean   :3.23  
#>  3rd Qu.:141.0                      3rd Qu.:3.590   3rd Qu.:3.40  
#>  Max.   :326.0                      Max.   :3.940   Max.   :4.17  
#>  compressionratio   horsepower       peakrpm        citympg     
#>  Min.   : 7.000   Min.   : 48.0   Min.   :4200   Min.   :13.00  
#>  1st Qu.: 8.500   1st Qu.: 70.0   1st Qu.:4800   1st Qu.:19.00  
#>  Median : 9.000   Median : 95.0   Median :5200   Median :24.00  
#>  Mean   : 8.848   Mean   :106.2   Mean   :5182   Mean   :24.85  
#>  3rd Qu.: 9.400   3rd Qu.:116.0   3rd Qu.:5500   3rd Qu.:30.00  
#>  Max.   :11.500   Max.   :288.0   Max.   :6600   Max.   :49.00  
#>    highwaympg        price      
#>  Min.   :16.00   Min.   : 5118  
#>  1st Qu.:25.00   1st Qu.: 7609  
#>  Median :30.00   Median : 9980  
#>  Mean   :30.48   Mean   :12999  
#>  3rd Qu.:34.00   3rd Qu.:16430  
#>  Max.   :54.00   Max.   :45400

# Use head() to display the first few rows of the data
head(data)



  




#3
# Include all potential regressors
lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data=data)
summary(lm_all)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

#Let’s build a second regression model, where we only include variables that were statistically significant in the previous model.

# Include only significant regressors
lm_imp <- lm(price ~ enginetype + cylindernumber + enginesize + stroke + peakrpm, data = data)
summary(lm_imp)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ enginetype + cylindernumber + enginesize + 
#>     stroke + peakrpm, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -6032.7 -1231.6  -157.4  1163.4  8091.3 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -3.803e+03  4.584e+03  -0.830 0.407877    
#> enginetypedohcv      -5.351e+03  3.247e+03  -1.648 0.101253    
#> enginetypel           4.275e+03  1.371e+03   3.117 0.002150 ** 
#> enginetypeohc         3.508e+03  8.723e+02   4.022 8.74e-05 ***
#> enginetypeohcf        7.758e+02  1.117e+03   0.695 0.488171    
#> enginetypeohcv       -6.654e+03  1.249e+03  -5.327 3.19e-07 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -6.220e+03  2.538e+03  -2.451 0.015291 *  
#> cylindernumberfour   -9.089e+03  2.491e+03  -3.649 0.000352 ***
#> cylindernumbersix    -5.299e+03  1.863e+03  -2.844 0.005015 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree  -5.904e+03  4.110e+03  -1.437 0.152688    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -1.821e+04  3.001e+03  -6.070 8.34e-09 ***
#> enginesize            1.990e+02  1.091e+01  18.242  < 2e-16 ***
#> stroke               -6.225e+03  8.397e+02  -7.414 5.86e-12 ***
#> peakrpm               3.393e+00  4.888e-01   6.941 8.21e-11 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2559 on 167 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9067, Adjusted R-squared:  0.8994 
#> F-statistic: 124.8 on 13 and 167 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



#4.1
# Assuming 'enginetype' is a categorical variable
str(data$enginetype)

#>  chr [1:181] "dohc" "dohc" "ohcv" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" ...

# Unique values it can take on
unique_values <- unique(data$enginetype)
print(unique_values)

#> [1] "dohc"  "ohcv"  "ohc"   "l"     "ohcf"  "dohcv"



#4.2 & 4.3
# Fit a linear regression model with 'enginetype' as the only predictor
model_enginetype <- lm(price ~ enginetype, data =data)
summary(model_enginetype)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ enginetype, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#> -11599  -4237  -2171   1872  30223 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                 Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)        18116       2031   8.919 6.15e-16 ***
#> enginetypedohcv    13284       7324   1.814  0.07142 .  
#> enginetypel        -4324       3346  -1.292  0.19802    
#> enginetypeohc      -7025       2121  -3.312  0.00112 ** 
#> enginetypeohcf     -4378       2725  -1.606  0.10999    
#> enginetypeohcv      6982       2817   2.479  0.01414 *  
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7037 on 175 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.2605, Adjusted R-squared:  0.2394 
#> F-statistic: 12.33 on 5 and 175 DF,  p-value: 2.981e-10


When compared to the reference level, the ‘enginetypeohc’ and ‘enginetypeohcv’ categories have statistically significant effects on the price. The other categories (‘enginetypedohcv,’ ‘enginetypel,’ and ‘enginetypeohcf’) do not have statistically significant effects based on the p-values.  enginetypeohc: The estimated decrease in price for cars with ‘enginetypeohc’ compared to the reference level is $7,025. The p-value (0.00112) is less than 0.05, so the effect is statistically significant at the 0.05 significance level.  enginetypeohcv: The estimated increase in price for cars with ‘enginetypeohcv’ compared to the reference level is $6,982. The p-value (0.01414) is less than 0.05, so the effect is statistically significant at the 0.05 significance level.  Changing the value of ‘enginetype’ involves comparing the effect of different engine types on the predicted price

#5

library(dplyr)

# Add a new variable 'seat_heating' with value TRUE for all observations
new_df <- data %>% mutate(seat_heating = TRUE)

# Run a regression with the new variable
model_with_seat_heating <- lm(price ~ . + seat_heating, data = new_df)

# Print the summary of the linear regression model
summary(model_with_seat_heating)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ . + seat_heating, data = new_df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#>

#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)

#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824

#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> seat_heatingTRUE             NA         NA      NA       NA    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


Perfect Collinearity: If the new variable has the same value for all observations (in this case, TRUE for all), it will lead to perfect collinearity. Perfect collinearity occurs when one variable can be exactly predicted from another variable or a combination of other variables in the model. In such cases, the regression model cannot estimate the coefficients separately, resulting in NA coefficients.  Perfect Prediction: If the new variable is perfectly predictive of the dependent variable, the regression model may not be able to estimate the coefficients due to perfect prediction. This can occur when there is no variability in the dependent variable within each level of the new variable.

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
#1
# Load packages
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

# create DAG from dagitty
dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
D [exposure,pos="0.075,0.4"]
Y [outcome,pos="0.4,0.4"]
L [pos="0.2,0.2"]
S [pos="0.3,0.5"]
D -> Y
D -> L
S -> D
S -> Y
L -> S
}
'

# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model) +
  theme_dag() + # custom theme, can be left out
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "black")








D represents the treatment variable (having parking spots), Y represents the outcome variable (sales), L represents the location, and S represents the store.

data <- readRDS("C:/Users/Anjali/Downloads/Causal_Data_Science_Data (1)/Causal_Data_Science_Data/customer_sat.rds")

#2.1
#
model1 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = data)
summary(model1)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427



#2.2
# Assuming 'subscription' is another column in your dataset
model2 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = data)
summary(model2)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08



Model 1: Coefficients: Intercept: 78.8860 Follow-ups: -3.3093 Interpretation: The intercept (78.8860) represents the estimated satisfaction when the number of follow-up calls is zero. The coefficient for follow-ups (-3.3093) suggests that, on average, for each additional follow-up call, satisfaction decreases by approximately 3.31 units. Statistical Significance: Both intercept and follow-ups have p-values less than 0.05, indicating statistical significance. Model Fit: R²=0.658: Approximately 65.8% of the variability in satisfaction is explained by the number of follow-up calls.  Model 2: Coefficients: Intercept: 26.7667 Follow-ups: 2.1944 Subscription Premium: 44.7222 Subscription Premium+: 18.0722 Interpretation: The intercept (26.7667) represents the estimated satisfaction when follow-up calls and all subscription variables are zero. The coefficient for follow-ups (2.1944) suggests that, on average, for each additional follow-up call, satisfaction increases by approximately 2.19 units. The coefficients for subscription levels indicate the change in satisfaction compared to the baseline (assumed to be subscription Starter). Statistical Significance: All coefficients have p-values less than 0.05, indicating statistical significance. Model Fit: R² = 0.9597 : Approximately 95.97% of the variability in satisfaction is explained by follow-up calls and subscription levels.  Model 2 provides a more comprehensive understanding of the factors influencing satisfaction as it includes both follow-up calls and subscription levels. In Model 2, the positive coefficient for follow-ups suggests that more follow-up calls are associated with higher satisfaction. The subscription coefficients in Model 2 indicate that, compared to the baseline (Starter), both Premium and Premium+ subscriptions are associated with higher satisfaction. Overall, Model 2 suggests that, when accounting for subscription levels, both follow-up calls and subscription levels significantly contribute to explaining satisfaction. The high R² value in Model 2 indicates that the combination of follow-up calls and subscription levels explains a large portion of the variability in satisfaction


#4
# Assuming 'follow_ups', 'satisfaction', and 'subscription' are column names in dataset
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

# Create a DAG model manually
dag_model <- dagitty('dag {
  follow_ups [exposure,pos="1,1"]
  satisfaction [outcome,pos="2,1"]
  subscription [pos="3,1"]

  subscription -> satisfaction
  follow_ups -> satisfaction
}')

# plot adjustment sets
ggdag_adjustment_set(dag_model, shadow = T) +
  theme_minimal() + # custom theme, can be left out
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "white")

title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.
